title: 114_hr1145
content: The Biomass Thermal Utilization Act of 2015, also known as the BTU Act of 2015, includes a Residential Energy-Efficient Property Credit for biomass fuel property expenditures. The BTU Act of 2015 introduces a Residential Energy-Efficient Property Credit for biomass fuel property expenditures, allowing a 30 percent credit for qualified biomass fuel property expenditures made before January 1, 2021. The BTU Act of 2015 introduces a Residential Energy-Efficient Property Credit for biomass fuel property expenditures, allowing a 30 percent credit for qualified biomass fuel property expenditures made before January 1, 2021. Biomass fuel property expenditure refers to an expenditure for property that uses biomass fuel to heat a dwelling unit in the US with a thermal efficiency rating of at least 75 percent. Biomass fuel includes plant-derived fuels like agricultural crops, trees, wood, and grasses. The amendments made by this section apply to expenditures for biomass fuel property paid or incurred in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015. Investment tax credit for biomass heating property applies to expenditures for biomass fuel property in taxable years after December 31, 2015. Investment tax credit for biomass heating property is amended to include open-loop biomass heating property with specific efficiency requirements for thermal output. The text discusses amendments to the Energy percentage credits under section 48(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically increasing the credit for energy property described in paragraph (3)(A)(viii) to 15 percent for periods ending before January 1, 2021. The text discusses amending section 48(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code to increase the credit for energy property with a thermal output efficiency of at least 80 percent. The amendments apply to periods after December 31, 2015, in taxable years ending after that date. The text discusses amending section 48(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code to increase the credit for energy property with a thermal output efficiency of at least 80 percent. This amendment applies to periods after December 31, 2015, in taxable years ending after that date, under rules similar to section 48(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
